How do you know if you can use 
a 
binomial distribution?

3

1.
Each trial has only 2 possible outcomes: 
“success” (1) or “failure” (0)


2.
You conduct each “trial” exactly the same way 
for a fixed number of times 
n


3.
The probability of success 
p
 is the same for 
each trial


4.
Trials are independent

Can you use a binomial distribution?

4

Sample students until you’ve found one who likes cats.

X = number of students sampled.

Probability of a student liking cats is 28%.

https://online.stat.psu.edu/stat414/lesson/10/10.2

Can you use a binomial distribution?

X = number of students sampled.

Probability of a student liking cats is 28%.

Nope, no 
n
 defined!

The Greed Game: each round

20

https://www.statsmedic.com/apstats-chapter6-day9
 

●
If I roll a 1-5, you get +1 point

●
If I roll a 6, you reset to 0 points 
and you’re out of the game

●
You can sit down at any time (if a 6 
has not yet been rolled) and keep 
the points you’ve accumulated

https://woodexpressions.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/03/Greed.jpg

The Greed Game: rules

21

●
Everyone starts by standing

●
I roll a dice simulator once each round

●
On your whiteboard:
 track your points 
(update each round): +1 for any 1-5 roll

●
Sit down 
when you choose to stop
 playing, 
or 
when I roll a 6 
(reset to 0 points)

●
Game ends when a 6 is rolled; winner has 
most points


https://www.statsmedic.com/apstats-chapter6-day9
 

https://woodexpressions.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/03/Greed.jpg

22

I will be using Google’s unbiased 6-sided dice

Was there cheating?!

23

●
How many points did the winner(s) 
have?

●
How expected/unexpected is this?

●
How can we tell?

PMF vs. CDF

26

●
How do we express the probability 
that we’re looking to calculate?

●
Let’s assume our story X = the time 
to reach “success”

○
“Success” = # rolls until game end 
(which could be way after the 
winner of the game sits down)

https://woodexpressions.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/03/Greed.jpg

PMF vs. CDF

27

●
X = the time to reach the end of the game

●
Let 
k
 = some integer

●
What is the difference between P(X=k) 
and P(X≥k)?

https://woodexpressions.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/03/Greed.jpg

PMF vs. CDF

28

●
X = the time to reach the end of the game

●
Let 
k
 = some integer

●
What is the difference between P(X=k) 
and P(X≥k)?

○
P(X=k) is the probability that it takes k time exactly for the 
game to end (i.e. a 6 is rolled on the k
th
 round). 
 
P(X≥k) is the 
probability that it takes 
at least
 k time for the game to end 
(i.e., a 6 was definitely 
not
 rolled in the first k-1 rounds).

https://woodexpressions.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/03/Greed.jpg

29

●
X = the time to reach the end of the game

●
To model the probability that someone 
wins the Greed Game with 
k-1
 points, 
should we use 
P(X=k) or P(X≥k)
?


PMF vs. CDF

琀
琀
 

https://woodexpressions.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/03/Greed.jpg

30

●
X = the time to reach the end of the game

●
To model the probability that someone 
wins the Greed Game with 
k-1
 points, 
should we use P(X=k) or 
P(X≥k)
?

Someone wins by necessarily sitting down 
before
 a 6 is rolled. 
 
They must also be the last person to sit down, meaning no one 
else will be standing after the winner sits. So, 
if the winner sits at
 
time 
k
, the 6 could be rolled anytime after k
, hence ending the 
game.  This means we care more about P(X≥k).

PMF vs. CDF

https://woodexpressions.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/03/Greed.jpg

55

1.
No packages:
 calculate the pmf or cdf using 
the formulas we just used


2.

generate the geometric distribution


3.
Scipy: 
use scipy.stats.geom to then call 
functions like pmf() and cdf()

Geometric Distribution in Python

No need for k 
because this just 
gives you a 
random draw from 
a geometric 
distribution

How many draws you want 
from the distribution

in Python

Recap on geometric distribution:

58

Use when...

1.
Each trial has only 2 possible outcomes: 
“success” (1) or “failure” (0)


2.
You conduct each “trial” exactly the same way 
and 
count the # trials until the first success


3.
The probability of success 
p
 is the same for 
each trial


4.
Trials are independent
